businesses.name: Politics and Prose

history.story: Two friends quit their government jobs to open a small bookshop. They built it into a nationally renowned literary institution that has hosted every major author from the past four decades. The store survived the rise of Amazon and big box stores by becoming a community gathering place.
history.what_was_here_before: This stretch of Connecticut Avenue was developed in the 1950s as suburban retail expanded north from downtown DC. The building previously housed various small retail shops.
history.neighborhood_context: Politics and Prose anchors the Connecticut Avenue commercial corridor, drawing visitors from across the region and helping maintain Tenleytown's identity as a walkable, culturally vibrant neighborhood.

businesses.description: Independent bookstore and coffeehouse known for author events, book clubs, and a carefully curated selection. Features an in-store cafe, extensive children's section, and hosts hundreds of author events annually.

businesses.name: Bread Furst

history.story: Master baker Mark Furstenberg, who previously founded Marvelous Market, returned to baking after years of teaching and consulting. He brought old-world techniques and a commitment to whole grains to upper Connecticut Avenue.
history.what_was_here_before: The space was previously occupied by retail shops in what was part of Van Ness's mid-century commercial development along the Connecticut Avenue corridor.
history.neighborhood_context: Bread Furst represents the neighborhood's evolution toward artisanal food, part of a broader trend of independent specialty shops replacing chain retail.

businesses.description: Artisan bakery specializing in traditional breads, pastries, and sandwiches. Known for using whole grains, natural fermentation, and European baking techniques.

businesses.name: Medium Rare

history.story: Chef Mark Bucher revolutionized the steakhouse concept with a simple premise: one dish, done perfectly. The no-menu restaurant serves only steak frites with secret sauce, salad, and bread. The concept was so successful it spawned locations across the region.
history.what_was_here_before: Wisconsin Avenue in Tenleytown has been a commercial corridor since the streetcar era. This building housed various retail and restaurant tenants throughout the 20th century.
history.neighborhood_context: Medium Rare became a neighborhood institution, proving that Tenleytown could support destination dining beyond its traditional role as a convenience retail strip.

businesses.description: No-menu steakhouse serving one thing: culotte steak with secret sauce, hand-cut fries, mixed greens, and artisan bread. Reservations recommended.

businesses.name: Millie's

history.story: Located in the historic Sears building, Millie's brought a sophisticated all-day cafe to Spring Valley. The restaurant honors the building's retail heritage while creating a new community gathering space.
history.what_was_here_before: This was the flagship Sears Roebuck store from 1941 until 2001. The art deco building was a retail anchor for the entire northwest DC region, representing the height of suburban commercial development.
history.neighborhood_context: The Sears building's transformation into mixed-use space with Millie's represents Spring Valley's evolution from car-oriented retail to walkable neighborhood dining.

businesses.description: All-day cafe in the historic Sears building serving New American cuisine. Features a stylish interior, seasonal menu, and extensive brunch offerings.

businesses.name: Sfoglina

history.story: Celebrity chef Fabio Trabocchi brought his casual pasta concept to Van Ness, expanding beyond his fine-dining restaurants. The focus on handmade Emilia-Romagna style pasta brought destination dining to the corridor.
history.what_was_here_before: This location on Connecticut Avenue was part of the mid-century commercial development that followed the opening of the Van Ness UDC Metro station in 1981.
history.neighborhood_context: Sfoglina helped establish Van Ness as a dining destination, joining other restaurants in transforming the formerly sleepy corridor into a food hub.

businesses.description: Casual pasta house featuring handmade Emilia-Romagna style pasta. Sister restaurant to the acclaimed Fiola. Known for fresh pasta made daily on-site.

businesses.name: Guapo's

history.story: A Tenleytown institution for over three decades, Guapo's has served generations of neighborhood families and AU students. The spacious patio and margaritas are legendary.
history.what_was_here_before: Wisconsin Avenue through Tenleytown was the main commercial strip serving the neighborhood since the streetcar era. This section developed primarily after World War II.
history.neighborhood_context: Guapo's is one of the longest-running restaurants in Tenleytown, surviving multiple economic cycles and ownership changes while maintaining its neighborhood character.

businesses.description: Tex-Mex restaurant known for generous portions, strong margaritas, and a spacious patio. A neighborhood institution since 1990.

businesses.name: Z-Burger

history.story: Started as a single burger joint near AU, Z-Burger grew into a local chain known for Halal burgers and creative milkshakes. The Tenleytown location remains a student favorite.
history.what_was_here_before: This section of Wisconsin Avenue has been commercial since the early 20th century, evolving from general stores to modern fast-casual dining.
history.neighborhood_context: Z-Burger represents the quick-service dining that serves both the AU student population and busy Tenleytown commuters.

businesses.description: Fast-casual burger joint known for build-your-own burgers, creative milkshakes, and Halal-certified meat. Popular with students and families.

businesses.name: Whole Foods Market

history.story: The Tenleytown Whole Foods was one of the first in DC, opening at the turn of the millennium and helping establish the natural/organic grocery trend in the city.
history.what_was_here_before: This location sits on what was once part of the commercial strip that developed after the streetcar connected Tenleytown to downtown.
history.neighborhood_context: Whole Foods anchors Tenleytown's grocery options, complementing the area's walkable urban village character.

businesses.description: Natural and organic grocery store with prepared foods, bakery, and extensive produce section.

businesses.name: Best Buy

history.story: The Tenleytown Best Buy occupies what was once the Sears Auto Center, part of the broader Sears complex that dominated this section of Wisconsin Avenue.
history.what_was_here_before: This was the Sears automotive service center, part of the Sears Roebuck retail complex built in the 1940s. The main Sears building is now home to other retail.
history.neighborhood_context: Best Buy represents the evolution of Wisconsin Avenue from traditional department store retail to modern big-box format.

businesses.description: Electronics retailer offering computers, TVs, appliances, and tech services. Features Geek Squad support center.

businesses.name: Tenley Mini Mart

history.story: A neighborhood corner store that has served Tenleytown residents and AU students for decades. Known for convenience, friendly service, and being the go-to spot for late-night essentials.
history.what_was_here_before: Corner stores have operated at this location since the early 20th century, evolving with the neighborhood's needs.
history.neighborhood_context: Tenley Mini Mart represents the traditional neighborhood convenience store model, surviving despite chain competition.

businesses.description: Neighborhood convenience store with groceries, snacks, beverages, and household essentials. Family-owned and operated.

businesses.name: American University

history.story: American University was founded to be a 'national university' training public servants. The campus was used for chemical weapons research during WWI, and unexploded ordnance is still occasionally discovered in Spring Valley.
history.what_was_here_before: The 84-acre campus was assembled from farmland in the early 1890s. The location was chosen for its elevation and distance from the city center.
history.neighborhood_context: AU shapes the entire neighborhood, from student housing demand to the cultural character of Wisconsin Avenue businesses.

businesses.description: Private research university known for programs in international relations, public affairs, and communications. Home to 14,000 students.

businesses.name: Starbucks

history.story: One of the first Starbucks in upper northwest DC, this location marked the coffee chain's expansion into neighborhood commercial districts beyond downtown.
history.what_was_here_before: This section of Wisconsin Avenue has housed various small retail since the streetcar era.
history.neighborhood_context: The Starbucks serves as an informal community gathering spot and student study space.

businesses.description: Coffee shop chain offering espresso drinks, teas, pastries, and light fare. Popular study and meeting spot.

businesses.name: Comet Ping Pong

history.story: A neighborhood pizza joint that became famous for hosting live music in its back room with ping pong tables. The venue helped launch several DC bands and became a community cultural space.
history.what_was_here_before: The Connecticut Avenue corridor through upper northwest developed commercially after the streetcar line extended north in the early 20th century.
history.neighborhood_context: Comet Ping Pong represents the creative, arts-oriented character of the Connecticut Avenue corridor, mixing family dining with live music.

businesses.description: Pizza restaurant with ping pong tables and live music venue. Known for wood-fired pizza, craft beer, and all-ages shows.

businesses.name: Aldom Cleaners

history.story: One of Tenleytown's longest-operating family businesses, Aldom has served neighborhood residents for over 60 years, including multiple generations of the same families.
history.what_was_here_before: Dry cleaning services have operated in this commercial strip since the post-war suburban expansion.
history.neighborhood_context: Aldom represents the enduring local business tradition that gives Tenleytown its neighborhood character.

businesses.description: Family-owned dry cleaning and laundry service. Known for quality work and personalized service for over 60 years.

businesses.name: Tenley Hardware

history.story: A true neighborhood hardware store that knows its customers by name. Tenley Hardware has survived the big-box era by offering expert advice and stocking items for the area's older homes.
history.what_was_here_before: Hardware stores have served Tenleytown since the neighborhood was developed in the early 20th century.
history.neighborhood_context: Tenley Hardware is essential for maintaining the neighborhood's housing stock, much of which dates to the 1920s-1940s.

businesses.description: Neighborhood hardware store with knowledgeable staff, repair supplies, and items for older DC homes. Known for helpful service.

businesses.name: AU Park Cleaners

history.story: Serving the AU Park neighborhood for over 50 years, this cleaner has been the go-to for families, diplomats, and professionals living in the quiet residential streets.
history.what_was_here_before: The small commercial node at this location developed to serve the AU Park residential area.
history.neighborhood_context: AU Park Cleaners anchors one of the few commercial spots in the otherwise residential AU Park neighborhood.

businesses.description: Neighborhood dry cleaner serving AU Park residents with quality cleaning, alterations, and same-day service.

businesses.name: Surfside

history.story: Surfside brought California-style tacos and beach vibes to Wisconsin Avenue. The casual concept was designed to feel like a SoCal taco stand.
history.what_was_here_before: This stretch of Wisconsin Avenue has been commercial since the streetcar era, with various food service establishments over the decades.
history.neighborhood_context: Surfside represents the newer wave of fast-casual concepts targeting young professionals and families.

businesses.description: California-style taco stand serving fish tacos, burritos, and Mexican-inspired fare with a beach vibe.

businesses.name: Sprint Mart

history.story: A Spring Valley institution serving one of DC's most affluent neighborhoods with convenience goods and friendly service for nearly 60 years.
history.what_was_here_before: The Spring Valley shopping area developed in the 1930s-40s alongside the neighborhood's residential growth.
history.neighborhood_context: Sprint Mart serves the daily needs of Spring Valley residents in an area with limited walkable retail options.

businesses.description: Neighborhood convenience store serving Spring Valley with groceries, prepared foods, and household essentials.

businesses.name: CVS Pharmacy

history.story: CVS replaced an earlier drugstore at this location, continuing the tradition of pharmacy services on Wisconsin Avenue that dates back decades.
history.what_was_here_before: Independent pharmacies served Tenleytown from the early 20th century until the chain pharmacy era.
history.neighborhood_context: CVS provides essential pharmacy services near the Tenleytown Metro station.

businesses.description: Full-service pharmacy with prescription services, health products, and convenience items.

businesses.name: Raku

history.story: Raku brought Pan-Asian cuisine to the Van Ness corridor, becoming a neighborhood staple for sushi, noodles, and Asian fusion dishes.
history.what_was_here_before: The Van Ness commercial strip developed significantly after the Metro station opened in 1981.
history.neighborhood_context: Raku is part of the diverse dining options that transformed Van Ness from a residential corridor into a food destination.

businesses.description: Pan-Asian restaurant offering sushi, noodles, and fusion dishes in a contemporary setting.

businesses.name: Le Petit Plats

history.story: A cozy French bistro that brought authentic Parisian small plates to the Woodley Park neighborhood, filling a niche for intimate dining.
history.what_was_here_before: The Woodley Park commercial corridor has served the neighborhood since the early 20th century.
history.neighborhood_context: Le Petit Plats contributes to Woodley Park's reputation for neighborhood dining.

businesses.description: French bistro serving classic small plates in an intimate setting. Known for wine selection and authentic Parisian atmosphere.

businesses.name: Washington Sports Club

history.story: The Tenleytown sports club has served neighborhood fitness enthusiasts for decades, evolving from a basic gym to a full-service fitness center.
history.what_was_here_before: This commercial area developed in the mid-20th century as Tenleytown grew.
history.neighborhood_context: The gym serves the health-conscious upper northwest population with convenient Metro access.

businesses.description: Full-service fitness center with cardio equipment, weights, group classes, and personal training.

businesses.name: Janette's

history.story: A neighborhood breakfast and lunch spot that has been feeding Connecticut Avenue regulars for nearly 40 years. Known for hearty portions and friendly service.
history.what_was_here_before: Small restaurants and cafes have served this corridor since the streetcar era.
history.neighborhood_context: Janette's is a classic neighborhood diner, a gathering spot for longtime residents and newcomers alike.

businesses.description: Neighborhood cafe serving breakfast and lunch with hearty American fare, friendly service, and reasonable prices.

businesses.name: Masala Art

history.story: Masala Art brought upscale Indian cuisine to Tenleytown, elevating the neighborhood's dining options with creative takes on traditional dishes.
history.what_was_here_before: Wisconsin Avenue in Tenleytown has been commercial since the early 20th century.
history.neighborhood_context: Masala Art represents the evolution of neighborhood dining toward more diverse, chef-driven concepts.

businesses.description: Contemporary Indian restaurant offering creative takes on traditional dishes. Known for lunch buffet and elegant dinner service.

businesses.name: Maggiano's Little Italy

history.story: The Friendship Heights Maggiano's opened as part of the Chevy Chase Pavilion retail development, bringing family-style Italian dining to the upscale shopping district.
history.what_was_here_before: The Chevy Chase Pavilion was built in the 1990s as part of the retail expansion at the DC-Maryland border.
history.neighborhood_context: Maggiano's serves shoppers and residents in the Friendship Heights retail district.

businesses.description: Family-style Italian-American restaurant with generous portions, classic dishes, and private dining rooms.
